skill.name: verification-before-completion
skill.description: Use when about to claim work is complete, fixed, or passing, before committing or creating PRs - requires running verification commands and confirming output before making any success claims; evidence before assertions always
skill.summary: Use when about to claim work is complete, fixed, or passing, before committing or creating PRs - req...
skill.author: Cygnusfear

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and guidelines. All 30 static findings are false positives: markdown code fences misinterpreted as shell backticks, git terminology misidentified as C2/crypto indicators, and legitimate verification terms flagged as reconnaissance. No code execution, file access, or network activity occurs.

content.value_statement: Stop false completion claims that waste time and damage trust. This skill forces fresh verification evidence before any success assertions.
actual_capabilities: Forces verification commands before completion claims
Provides red flag detection for risky language

use_cases.title: Prevent premature commits
use_cases.description: Verify tests pass and builds succeed before committing code to avoid breaking builds

use_cases.title: Validate bug fixes properly
use_cases.description: Run regression tests to confirm bugs are actually fixed before marking tickets complete

use_cases.title: Ensure quality standards
use_cases.description: Enforce verification discipline across team before accepting work as complete

prompt_templates.title: Before committing
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to verify my work before claiming completion. What specific command should I run to prove this works? Run it now and show me the output.

prompt_templates.title: After fixing bugs
prompt_templates.prompt: Before I say this bug is fixed, I need to run verification. What test confirms the fix? Run it fresh and show results.

prompt_templates.title: Before pull request
prompt_templates.prompt: I am about to create a PR. Run the full test suite and build process. Show me the complete output before I claim it is ready.

prompt_templates.title: After agent work
prompt_templates.prompt: An agent said the task is complete. I need to verify independently. Show me the VCS diff and run any relevant tests to confirm.

output_examples.input: I think the tests should pass now
output: You said should pass without verification
Required: Run test command, Show output, Then claim
Example: npm test, Shows 45 passing, All tests pass

output_examples.input: The build looks good, time to push
output: Rule violation: Expression of satisfaction before verification
Looking good is not verification evidence
Run the build command, Check exit code, Read full output
Only then claim pass or fail with actual evidence

output_examples.input: I am confident the bug is fixed
output: Run the specific test that reproduces the original bug
Show the test output proving the fix works
Then report actual status with verification attached

best_practices: Always run full verification commands fresh
Read complete output before claiming success
Apply rule to all success implications

faq.question: Does this replace my testing workflow?
faq.answer: No, it enforces discipline within your existing workflow by requiring verification evidence before claims.

faq.question: What if I am absolutely sure it works?
faq.answer: Confidence does not equal evidence. Run the verification anyway - the rule has no exceptions.

faq.question: Can I use this with automated CI/CD?
faq.answer: Yes, it ensures you verify locally before pushing, complementing automated pipeline checks.

faq.question: How does this handle different project types?
faq.answer: The skill adapts to your project verification commands - tests, builds, linters, whatever proves correctness.

faq.question: What happens if verification fails?
faq.answer: Report the actual status with evidence. Never claim success when verification shows failures.

faq.question: Is this too strict for rapid development?
faq.answer: False claims waste more time than verification. The discipline prevents costly rework and maintains trust.
